Article.ArticleTitle: NO to NO<sub>2</sub> Conversion Rate Analysis and Implications for Dispersion Model Chemistry Methods using Las Vegas, Nevada Near-Road Field Measurements.

AbstractText: The nitrogen dioxide/oxides of nitrogen (NO<sub>2</sub>/NO<sub>X</sub>) ratio is an important surrogate for NO to NO<sub>2</sub> chemistry in dispersion models when estimating NO<sub>X</sub> impacts in a near-road environment. Existing dispersion models use different techniques and assumptions to represent NO to NO<sub>2</sub> conversion and do not fully characterize all of the important atmospheric chemical and mechanical processes. Thus, "real-world" ambient measurements must be analyzed to assess the behavior of NO<sub>2</sub>/NO<sub>X</sub> ratios near roadways. An examination of NO<sub>2</sub>/NO<sub>X</sub> ratio data from a field study conducted in Las Vegas, Nevada (NV), from mid-December, 2008 through mid-December, 2009 provides insights into the appropriateness of assumptions about the NO<sub>2</sub>/NO<sub>X</sub> ratio included in dispersion models. Data analysis indicates multiple factors affect the downwind NO<sub>2</sub>/NO<sub>X</sub> ratio. These include spatial gradient, background ozone (O<sub>3</sub>), source emissions of NO and NO<sub>2</sub>, and background NO<sub>2</sub>/NO<sub>X</sub> ratio. Analysis of the NO<sub>2</sub>/NO<sub>X</sub> ratio spatial gradient indicates that under high O<sub>3</sub> conditions, the change in the ratio is fairly constant once a certain O<sub>3</sub> threshold (≥ 30 ppb) is reached. However, under low O<sub>3</sub> conditions (< 30 ppb), there are differences between weekdays and weekends, most likely due to a decline in O<sub>3</sub> concentrations during the weekday morning hours, reducing the O<sub>3</sub> available to titrate the emitted NO, allowing lower NO<sub>2</sub>/NO<sub>X</sub> ratios. These results suggest that under high O<sub>3</sub> conditions, NO<sub>X</sub> chemistry is driving the NO<sub>2</sub>/NO<sub>X</sub> ratios whereas under low O<sub>3</sub> conditions, atmospheric mixing is the driving factor.
